<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B> <A NAME="dm13301_item_7._management_s_discussio__ite03668"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dm13301_1"> </A>
ITEM 7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS    <BR>    </B></FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following discussion and analysis of our financial condition and results of operations should be read in conjunction with, and are qualified by reference to,
our Consolidated Financial Statements and related notes thereto in Item&nbsp;8 of this report and Selected Financial Data included in Item&nbsp;6 of this report. On March&nbsp;19, 2008, we
identified an error related to the classification of certain investments, principally auction rate securities, which were incorrectly classified as cash and cash equivalents rather than marketable
securities. The following management's discussion and analysis gives affect to the restatement discussed in Note&nbsp;18 to our Consolidated Financial Statements. Certain statements set forth below
under this caption constitute "forward-looking statements" within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform of 1995. Refer to the "Cautionary Statement About Forward Looking Statements"
preceding Item&nbsp;1 of this report. Also, for a discussion of certain risk factors applicable to our business and operations see "Risk Factors" in Item&nbsp;1A of this report. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
were founded in 1984 as a clean coal company focused on developing our K-Fuel process. Our goal is to leverage a vertically integrated, coal-based platform to
deliver clean, efficient and affordable energy. We intend to meet the specific needs of public utility, industrial and international market customers by providing economical solutions to environmental
emission standards compared to other emission standard alternatives. Our proprietary K-Fuel process uses heat and pressure to physically and chemically transform high moisture,
low-Btu coals, such as sub-bituminous coal and lignite, into a more energy efficient, lower-emission fuel. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We,
along with, our engineering consultants, Bechtel Power Corporation, have completed the modifications and improvements of the design and efficiency of the equipment used in the
K-Fuel process. Bechtel and Evergreen's operations team at Fort Union completed successful testing of new operational systems that will support construction of future K-Fuel or
K-Direct facilities, including a enhanced standard processing tower design. This work signals that we and Bechtel have resolved the most substantive technical challenges to scaling and
commercializing our production process. In February 2007, we expanded our contractual relationship with Bechtel to assist with future designs of additional K-Fuel facilities we may build
or license, including any K-Fuel plants located at coal-fired power generating plants, which we refer to as K-Direct plants. On September&nbsp;19, 2007, we
amended and restated our umbrella agreement with Bechtel Power
Corporation. Through this new program management agreement, we committed to provide Bechtel with $1&nbsp;billion in construction contracts through 2013. This restated agreement increases the scope
of engineering, procurement and construction services which may be performed by Bechtel. We intend to use Bechtel's services to oversee both technical development and implementation of all new
facilities and existing plants, including both K-Fuel and K-Direct plants. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
Fort Union plant which was our first plant to implement the current K-Fuel process, has accomplished virtually all of the goals and objectives we set forth for this site.
Most notably, as a result of operations at the Fort Union plant, we have: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>proven
that the K-Fuel process works by increasing Btus and reducing mercury, sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxide and carbon dioxide emissions;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>successfully
completed the redesign and testing of new operational systems;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>upgraded
sufficient amounts of low-rank coal for utility and industrial customers who completed a number of test burns of K-Fuel refined coal with
favorable results;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>tested
and improved product handling processes and requirements and improved transportation issues. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>31</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=31,EFW="2184008",CP="EVERGREEN ENERGY INC.",DN="1",CHK=417804,FOLIO='31',FILE='DISK127:[08ZAG1.08ZAG13301]DM13301A.;20',USER='MBRADT',CD='21-MAR-2008;18:10' -->
<A NAME="page_dm13301_1_32"> </A>
<UL>
<UL>
</UL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
the reasons discussed below, we have chosen to suspend operations at our Fort Union plant and mine site. This will enable us to focus on future K-Fuel or
K-Direct plants by redirecting constrained resources, both capital and human, to focus on the commercialization of our process. Bechtel has completed the enhanced standard processing tower
design based upon the results of testing completed by us at the Fort Union plant. Additionally, suspending production at this site will further enable us to reduce our cash utilization. If the need
arises, we are positioned to resume operations at the Fort Union plant to demonstrate the technology or to provide K-Fuel product for test burns at utilities or other industrial sites. We
are also evaluating redeploying some of
the equipment to a future K-Fuel facility site. We recorded an asset impairment charge of $109.5&nbsp;million related to the Fort Union plant and mine site as of December&nbsp;31,
2007. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
condensed consolidated financial statements include our accounts and the accounts of our wholly and majority-owned subsidiaries, including the nine months ended December&nbsp;31,
2006 for Buckeye Industrial Mining&nbsp;Co. (acquisition date of April&nbsp;3, 2006). We consolidate all of our majority-owned subsidiaries and reflect as minority interest the portion of these
entities that we do not own and reflected in other long-term liabilities. Intercompany transactions and balances have been eliminated. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the quarter ended September&nbsp;30, 2007, we re-evaluated our segments and have expanded our segment presentation to four segments to better reflect how our results
of operations are now evaluated and allocations of capital resources are determined. The Plant segment primarily represents revenue and costs related to our Fort Union plant and our mine site in
Gillette, Wyoming. The Mining segment primarily represents our mining operations at our Buckeye location and includes certain marketing personnel, the ash disposal facility and the blending facility.
The C-lock segment reflects the operations related to our worldwide sub-license of a technology to standardize the measurement of carbon emissions in energy and agricultural
related activities. The Technology segment is comprised of all other operations that use, apply, own or otherwise advance our proprietary, patented K-Fuel process, including our
headquarters and related operations, activities of Evergreen Energy Asia Pacific and KFx Technology,&nbsp;LLC, which holds the licenses to our technology. Our operations are principally conducted in
the United States. We will continue to evaluate how we manage our business and, as necessary, adjust our segment reporting accordingly. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Significant Trends  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For the last several years, our operations have been focused on developing our technology and the construction of the Fort Union plant. As a result, we have
limited revenues from K-Fuel refined coal and, historically most of our costs are related to general and administrative expenses. With the addition of Buckeye, we have begun to generate
revenue and incurred more substantial mining costs. In the future, we plan to build, own and operate K-Fuel and K-Direct refineries domestically and internationally, both
wholly owned and through joint ventures. Through C-Lock Technology we plan to generate revenues from our first-of- its-kind web-based system
along with our patent-pending technology that accurately measures greenhouse gases and certifies these environmental improvements as carbon credits. As our operations expand, we expect our revenue and
cost structure will also increase. The following discussion and analysis is focused on the events and trends that we believe have or will in the future have the most significant impact on our
business. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Revenue Trends  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In the future we expect to generate revenue from the following sources: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>coal
sales from our Buckeye operations;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>revenues
from production facilities including K-Fuel and K-Direct plants domestically and internationally; </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>32</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=32,EFW="2184008",CP="EVERGREEN ENERGY INC.",DN="1",CHK=537952,FOLIO='32',FILE='DISK127:[08ZAG1.08ZAG13301]DM13301A.;20',USER='MBRADT',CD='21-MAR-2008;18:10' -->
<A NAME="page_dm13301_1_33"> </A>
<UL>
<UL>
</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>revenues
from the measurement of carbon credits using our web-based patent-pending technology;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>licensing
of our technology, including license fees for constructing a plant and royalty fees for operating a plant; and </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
have granted certain rights and limited licenses for the use of certain K-Fuel technology, which may limit our revenue from production of K-Fuel refined coal
to the extent that the rights are exercised. See Note&nbsp;5 and 13 to our Consolidated Financial Statements for further details. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Expense Trends  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Fort Union  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have chosen to suspend operations at our Fort Union plant and mine site. This will enable us to focus on future K-Fuel or K-Direct
plants by redirecting constrained resources, both capital and human, to focus on the commercialization of our process. Bechtel has completed the enhanced standard processing tower design based upon
the results of testing completed by us at the Fort Union plant. Additionally, suspending production at this site will further enable us to reduce our cash expenditures. If the need arises, we are
positioned to resume operations at Fort Union plant to demonstrate the technology or to provide K-Fuel product for test burns at utilities or other industrial sites. We are also evaluating
redeploying some of the equipment to a future K-Fuel facility site. We will incur costs including labor, consulting and other costs to safely suspend operations at the plant. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Future K-Fuel and K-Direct facilities  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As we build future K-Fuel and K-Direct facilities and these facilities begin continuous operation, we will incur additional operational
expenses, the most significant being: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>coal
transportation costs;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>raw
material costs;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>outsourced
engineering and technical support;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>plant
maintenance costs;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>plant
personnel labor costs;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>fluid
processing costs;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>by-product
and water disposal costs; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>royalty
costs, relating to fees we owe to parties who own certain rights that support our patents and proprietary technology, primarily the Koppelman estate. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;See
further discussion of the royalty owed to the estate of Edward Koppelman in Note&nbsp;6&#151;Deferred Royalty Costs in Item&nbsp;8 of this report. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Coal mining operating expenses  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;With the acquisition of Buckeye we have incurred mine operating expenses including all costs associated with the mining of saleable coal and costs relating to our
coal ash disposal facility. As the price of coal increases, we anticipate increasing our production at both our surface mines and underground mines. We expect that the revenue generated from increased
production will exceed the incremental mining costs. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>33</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=33,EFW="2184008",CP="EVERGREEN ENERGY INC.",DN="1",CHK=616441,FOLIO='33',FILE='DISK127:[08ZAG1.08ZAG13301]DM13301A.;20',USER='MBRADT',CD='21-MAR-2008;18:10' -->
<A NAME="page_dm13301_1_34"> </A>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> General and administrative expenses  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As we identify business development opportunities, build new plants, and generally expand our business including hiring additional personnel at our corporate,
future plants and C-Lock locations and outsourced professional services, we will incur additional expenses, the most significant of which are: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>payroll
and related burdens;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>non-cash,
share-based compensation;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>business
development costs for potential future K-Fuel and K-Direct plants;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>rent
and utilities; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>professional
support fees. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
anticipate that accounting for non-cash, share-based compensation will add approximately $6.0&nbsp;million to $9.0&nbsp;million per year in the foreseeable future to
our expenses. In the event we should achieve certain performance goals, we would significantly accelerate recognition of these costs. Costs such as payroll and related burdens, professional support
fees and utilities are variable costs that increase with size and adding locations. As we build new plants and expand our vertical integration strategy, we expect these costs to increase in future
periods. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Results Of Operations  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Comparison of Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006  </I></B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Revenue  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenues for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 were $48.7&nbsp;million compared to $36.7&nbsp;million for the same period ended December&nbsp;31,
2006. The increase in revenue primarily relates to our April 2006 acquisition of Buckeye. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, we owned Buckeye for only nine months. During the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2007, we owned Buckeye for the entire twelve-month period. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenues
in our Mining segment for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 were $47.3&nbsp;million and $35.9&nbsp;million for the same period ended December&nbsp;31, 2006
respectively, as follows: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Coal
revenue includes mined raw and prepared coal sales within our Buckeye operations. Buckeye coal sales, including transportation costs charged to customers, for the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 were $39.4&nbsp;million or $54.13 sales realization per ton sold and $30.4&nbsp;million or $56.32 sales realization per ton sold for the period ended
December&nbsp;31, 2006. The decrease in the sales realization per ton sold for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 was due to a mix of types of coals sold during 2007 and downward pressure on
coal pricing, particularly during the first quarter of 2007 due depressed international coal prices. During periods of depressed coal pricing, we strategically adjust the mix of coal we produce to
focus less on our premium coals. As prices have improved in 2008, we began increasing production of our premium coals and anticipate that our sales realization per ton will increase in 2008, as
compared to 2007.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Brokered
coal sales net include the revenues reduced by costs associated with the purchase of coal from other coal producers, which we ship directly to customers. We
recognized $514,000 of net revenue for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 compared to $695,000 of net revenue for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. We enter into brokered coals sales as
opportunities arise or as needed to meet certain customers requests, and as a result, revenues in this area fluctuate.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Ash
disposal revenues primarily include revenues generated from the disposal of coal combustion bi-products at our ash pit in Ohio. Ash disposal revenues were
$7.4&nbsp;million and $4.7&nbsp;million for years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, respectively. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>34</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=34,EFW="2184008",CP="EVERGREEN ENERGY INC.",DN="1",CHK=322521,FOLIO='34',FILE='DISK127:[08ZAG1.08ZAG13301]DM13301A.;20',USER='MBRADT',CD='21-MAR-2008;18:10' -->
<A NAME="page_dm13301_1_35"> </A>
<UL>
<UL>
</UL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;K-Fuel
refined coal revenue is comprised of sales of our K-Fuel product to third parties. Blended K-Fuel refined coal revenue represents the
proportionate revenue related to K-Fuel that has been blended with other raw or prepared coal from our Buckeye operations and sold to third parties. The remaining revenue related to the
raw or prepared coal is reflected in Mining revenues. K-Fuel refined coal and blended K-Fuel refined coal sales were $1.1&nbsp;million and $420,000 for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, respectively and are included in our Plant segment. K-Fuel refined coal sales were less than expected primarily due to less production at our Fort Union
plant for both periods. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Coal Mining Operating Expenses  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our coal mining operating expenses include all costs associated with the mining of saleable coal and costs relating to our coal ash disposal facility at Buckeye,
which principally comprises our Mining segment. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Coal mining operating expenses  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Coal mining operating expenses include employee-related costs, outside contracted mining costs for our underground mines, internal and external coal
transportation costs, blasting, drilling, heavy equipment costs, purchased coal and other mining-related costs. Coal mining operating expenses were $38.3&nbsp;million and $28.9&nbsp;million for
the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, respectively. The increase can be attributed to the acquisition of Buckeye in April 2006, resulting in recording nine months of Buckeye's operation
for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 compared to recording twelve months of Buckeye's operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Ash disposal  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Ash disposal expenses include employee-related costs, consulting costs, costs of repairs and maintaining culverts and drainage ponds, transportation, and heavy
equipment costs and other costs associated with the ash disposal facility. Ash disposal expenses were $4.8&nbsp;million and $3.4&nbsp;million for the periods ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and
2006, respectively. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> General and Administrative  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Employee
non-cash, share-based compensation expenses were $19.0&nbsp;million and $9.8&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, respectively,
substantially all of which related to our Technology segment. The increase for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 compared to the same period ended in 2006 was primarily due to a
one-time $9.8&nbsp;million charge as a result of the termination of one of our executive officers and the acceleration of his restricted stock grant pursuant to his employment </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>35</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=35,EFW="2184008",CP="EVERGREEN ENERGY INC.",DN="1",CHK=802462,FOLIO='35',FILE='DISK127:[08ZAG1.08ZAG13301]DM13301A.;20',USER='MBRADT',CD='21-MAR-2008;18:10' -->
<A NAME="page_dm13301_1_36"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>agreement
and a one-time $661,000 charge related to the departure of another executive officer and the acceleration of vesting of his restricted stock grant. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2005, we entered into two agreements with Arch Coal,&nbsp;Inc. which allowed us to evaluate the potential of constructing and operating a plant at their Coal Creek mine site and
required us to issue warrants. In 2006, we extended these agreements to allow additional time for the evaluation of the project. In connection with the extension, the expiration date of the warrants
was also extended and, pursuant to SFAS&nbsp;123R, we were required to recognize an additional $1.7&nbsp;million of non-cash expense for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. Based
on discussions with Arch Coal, it was mutually agreed not to further extend these agreements. The first agreement expired on September&nbsp;30, 2006 and the warrant agreement expired on
October&nbsp;31, 2006. As market conditions and other circumstances change we may enter into new agreements with Arch Coal. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
increases for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 in comparison to the comparable period in 2006 were primarily due to a company-wide increase in health insurance
costs and adding personnel, including plant and engineering personnel. In addition, through the acquisition of Buckeye, we incurred twelve months of expense in 2007 compared to nine months of expense
in 2006. The small increase in the technology segment and the substantial increase in the plant segment were due to more corporate resources being used at our Fort Union plant during 2007 and the
associated allocation of those expenses. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
anticipation of hiring additional employees at our corporate office led to our office expansion and relocation in May 2007, and the related increases in rent, utilities and
relocation costs for the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 compared to the same period ended 2006. Our travel for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 increased due an increase in the number of trips to our Fort Union plant
as well as increased business development efforts. In addition, during the same period we incurred non-recurring charges relating to a loss on the sub-lease of our former
corporate office space and moving costs. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Insurance
and other costs primarily include costs related to our property and commercial liability, other insurance and all costs that cannot be categorized elsewhere and include, among
other costs, various business and franchise taxes, licensing fees, repair and maintenance, engineering and technical services and director expenses. The following table summarizes our insurance and
other costs related to each of our segments for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006. </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
increase for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 compared to the same period ended 2006 can be attributed to the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>A
licensing fee paid to the owner of the proprietary technology for the measurement of carbon emissions related to the formation of our subsidiary, C-Lock
Technology, Inc, which is reflected in the C-Lock segment;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Increase
in insurance due to the acquisition of Buckeye, which is reflected in the Mining segment;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Increase
in business development costs associated with the identification of key public utility leads, which are candidates for our process, and development of those leads,
which is reflected in the Technology segment; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Overall
increase in property and commercial liability premiums for our Fort Union plant, which is reflected in the Plant segment. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>37</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=37,EFW="2184008",CP="EVERGREEN ENERGY INC.",DN="1",CHK=325930,FOLIO='37',FILE='DISK127:[08ZAG1.08ZAG13301]DM13301A.;20',USER='MBRADT',CD='21-MAR-2008;18:10' -->
<A NAME="page_dm13301_1_38"> </A>
<UL>
<UL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Plant start-up costs  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Plant start-up costs include purchased raw materials, coal transportation, outsourced engineering and technical support, fluid processing,
by-products and water disposal, and employee-related costs, which are reflected in our Plant segment. Plant start-up costs remain higher than anticipated due to general
start-up issues with this first-of-a-kind plant and technical and operation improvements being implemented. Plant start-up costs were
$34.7&nbsp;million and $26.3&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, respectively. During the majority of the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, we were in the
construction and commissioning phases and most of the costs incurred during these phases were capitalized. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007, we were in the start-up phase and
a higher percentage of costs associated with the operations of our Fort Union plant were expensed as incurred. In addition, non-capitalized costs increased as a result of engineering and
technical work performed to improve and reconfigure our Fort Union plant. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Depreciation, Depletion and Amortization  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation, depletion and amortization are comprised of (1)&nbsp;depreciation on our Fort Union plant using the units-of-production
method, based on actual tons processed and depreciation on other fixed assets using the straight-line method; (2)&nbsp;depletion, based on actual tons mined at our mine sites in Ohio and
Wyoming; and (3)&nbsp;amortization related to our patents. Depreciation, depletion and amortization expenses were $8.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 compared to
$5.5&nbsp;million during the same period ended 2006. The increases are primarily attributable to the acquisition of Buckeye and the related depreciation and depletion on our mine sites and property
and equipment for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Research and Development  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Research and development costs include costs incurred to advance, test, or otherwise modify our proprietary technology or develop new technologies and primarily
include costs incurred to operate and maintain our laboratory facilities and professional engineering fees related to off-site testing of our K-Fuel refined coal. Research and
development costs were $876,000 and $1.4&nbsp;million for the years ended 2007 and 2006, respectively. The decrease is primarily a result of our Fort Union plant entering the start-up
phase of operation, which resulted in costs that were previously classified as research and development now being classified as plant start-up costs. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Cost of License and Consulting Revenue  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cost of license and consulting revenue includes costs to transfer our technology related to licensing and royalty agreements, including amortization of deferred
royalty costs, salaries and wages of certain personnel and professional fees. Cost of licensing and consulting revenue was $77,000 and $134,000 for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006,
respectively. The decreases in these costs were in direct correlation to the revenue recognized on the licensing agreement we entered into in 2004. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Asset Impairment Charges and Bad Debt  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Asset impairment and bad debt charges were $122.7&nbsp;million and $335,000 for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, respectively. Impairment
charges for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 are as follows: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
suspended operations at our Fort Union plant and mine site to allow us focus on future K-Fuel or K-Direct plants by redirecting constrained
resources, both capital and human, to focus on the commercialization of our process. We incurred impairment charges in our plant segment totalling $109.5&nbsp;million. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>38</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=38,EFW="2184008",CP="EVERGREEN ENERGY INC.",DN="1",CHK=420894,FOLIO='38',FILE='DISK127:[08ZAG1.08ZAG13301]DM13301A.;20',USER='MBRADT',CD='21-MAR-2008;18:10' -->
<A NAME="page_dm13301_1_39"> </A>
<UL>
<UL>
</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>Pursuant
to the guidance of Statements of Financial Accounting Standards No.&nbsp;144 "Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets", or
SFAS&nbsp;144, we are required to evaluate the fair value of our boiler, which is classified as held for sale. As result, of this fair value calculation we impaired the carrying value of our boiler
by $7.8&nbsp;million in our technology segment;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
impaired $3.6&nbsp;million of capitalized costs related to projects that we abandoned and/or replaced with more cost effective projects in our plant segment; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>we
impaired capital costs of 2.1&nbsp;million related to a previously announced future potential project with a major utility because it was determined not to be
economically feasible in our technology segment. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<BR>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Other Income Expense  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Interest income  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest income was $4.3&nbsp;million and $5.6&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, respectively. The decrease for the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 is attributed to interest earned on our cash balance, which was significantly lower compared to the same period in 2006. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Interest expense  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest expense for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and December&nbsp;31, 2006 was $3.4&nbsp;million and $6,000, respectively. The interest expense
relates to our long-term debt due 2012, which we completed in July 2007. We pay interest semi-annually at a rate of 8.00% per annum, due on February&nbsp;1 and
August&nbsp;1 of each year, beginning on February&nbsp;1, 2008. For additional information, see Note&nbsp;9&#151;Long-term Debt included in Item&nbsp;8 of this report. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><I> Other income (expense)  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007, other expense was $1.3&nbsp;million as compared to $1.1&nbsp;million of other income for the same period ended
2006. Pursuant to FAS&nbsp;133, we estimated the fair value of the embedded derivatives as of July&nbsp;30, 2007 when the notes were issued, and record those values as either assets or
liabilities. In addition, we are required to evaluate the fair value of the embedded derivatives at the end of each subsequent reporting period. We recognized a decrease in the fair value of the
derivatives of $1.7&nbsp;million. This fair value adjustment is a non-cash item and each quarter's estimation exercise is impacted, in part, by our stock price. For additional
information, see Note&nbsp;9&#151;Long-term Debt included in Item&nbsp;8 of this report. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
November&nbsp;26, 2003, we completed an equity exchange transaction with Rio Tinto Energy America Services Company ("RTEA"), formerly Kennecott Energy Company. As a part of the
exchange transaction, an intercompany working capital loan from Evergreen Energy to Pegasus Technologies&nbsp;Inc. with an outstanding balance of $9.4&nbsp;million was exchanged for a contingent
earn-out agreement of up to $9.4&nbsp;million in the aggregate, plus accrued interest (prime rate plus 500 basis points), payable out of a portion of future cash flows generated by
Pegasus. Due to the contingent nature of this potential stream of future cash flows, we did not recognize an asset or any associated income at the time of the exchange transaction. On May&nbsp;16,
2006, RTEA entered into a transaction involving its investment in Pegasus. Pursuant to the terms of the agreement entered into between us and RTEA dated November&nbsp;7, 2003, which triggered the
earn-out provision, we received a payment of $1.1&nbsp;million during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 from Pegasus as a payment in full satisfaction of the $9.4&nbsp;million
contingent obligation. This transaction had no effect on our note receivable from Pegasus with an outstanding balance of $87,000, net of an allowance of $1.2&nbsp;million, which is included in our
condensed consolidated balance sheet. We have been and expect to continue to, receive payments on this note. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>39</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=39,EFW="2184008",CP="EVERGREEN ENERGY INC.",DN="1",CHK=842962,FOLIO='39',FILE='DISK127:[08ZAG1.08ZAG13301]DM13301A.;20',USER='MBRADT',CD='21-MAR-2008;18:10' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_do13301_1_40"> </A>


<!-- COMMAND=ADD_BASECOLOR,"Black" -->




<!-- COMMAND=ADD_DEFAULTFONT,"font-family:times;" -->


 </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B><I>Comparison of Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005  </I></B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Revenue  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenues for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 were $36.7&nbsp;million compared to $984,000 for the same period ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. The
increase in revenue for the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 is substantially related to our April 2006 acquisition of Buckeye. Our Mining segment accounted for $35.8&nbsp;million in revenue
for the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
recognized revenue of $768,000 from the $7.5&nbsp;million up-front licensing fee received in December 2004 from Cook Inlet Coal&nbsp;LLC in our Technology segment for
the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. To date we have completed all of our contractual deliverables for the licensing fee and are waiting for Cook Inlet Coal to provide specific site information
before the next phase of revenue recognition can commence. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Coal Mining Operating Expenses  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our coal mining operating expenses include all costs associated with the mining of saleable coal and costs relating to our coal ash disposal facility at Buckeye,
which principally comprises our Mining segment. Coal mining operating expenses were $32.3&nbsp;million and $0 for the periods ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively. The increase in
coal mining operating expenses for the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 is related to our April 2006 acquisition of Buckeye. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Employee
non-cash, share-based compensation expenses were $9.8&nbsp;million and $2.2&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively,
substantially all of which related to our Technology segment. The increase in non-cash, share-based compensation was in direct correlation with the adoption of SFAS&nbsp;123(R) as of
January&nbsp;1, 2006. See
Note&nbsp;11&#151;Stock Options, Stock Grants and Employee Benefit Plans for further discussion in Item&nbsp;8 of this report. Non-cash, share based compensation in 2006
primarily related to restricted stock and option grants to our executive officers. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
2005, we entered into two agreements with Arch Coal,&nbsp;Inc. which allowed us to evaluate the potential of constructing and operating a plant at their Coal Creek mine site and
required us to issue warrants. In 2005, we incurred $5.8&nbsp;million of non-cash expense related to the issuance of these warrants to Arch Coal,&nbsp;Inc. In 2006, we extended these
agreements to allow additional time for the evaluation of the project. In connection with the extension, the expiration date of the warrants was also extended and, pursuant to SFAS&nbsp;123R, we
were required to recognize an additional $1.7&nbsp;million of non-cash expense for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. Based on discussions with Arch Coal, it was </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>40</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=40,EFW="2184008",CP="EVERGREEN ENERGY INC.",DN="1",CHK=836101,FOLIO='40',FILE='DISK127:[08ZAG1.08ZAG13301]DO13301A.;11',USER='CMATTI',CD='21-MAR-2008;15:25' -->
<A NAME="page_do13301_1_41"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>mutually
agreed not to further extend these agreements. The first agreement expired on September&nbsp;30, 2006 and the warrant agreement expired on October&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Employee-related
costs were $7.6&nbsp;million and $6.3&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively. The increases for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2006 were primarily related to an increase in the number of employees, which increased salaries and related burdens. During 2006, we added personnel in many areas, including
engineering and business development. In addition, the number of employees increased as a result of the Buckeye acquisition. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
majority of the increase is attributed to our increase in the number of employees at our corporate office and as a result of our acquisition of Buckeye. In addition, we increased our
travel </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>41</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_do13301_1_42"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>related
to our expanded business development efforts, including travel to our Ohio subsidiary and travel to identify potential sites for future plants. We also saw an increase in travel to our Fort
Union plant site by non-plant related employees and management in 2006, as the plant entered the startup phase. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table summarizes our insurance and other costs related to each of our segments for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
increase can be attributed primarily to an overall increase in property and commercial liability premiums for our corporate and our Buckeye operations. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Plant start-up costs  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Plant start-up costs were $26.3&nbsp;million and $1.5&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively. Plant
start-up costs were higher than anticipated due to general start up issues with this first-of-a-kind plant and
the acceleration of initial production runs. The commissioning of the facility at this accelerated pace resulted in a number of plant operating inefficiencies. We incurred higher feed stock costs as
we chose to purchase coal from a nearby mine and incurred trucking costs for the transportation of that purchased coal. Outsourced engineering and employee-related costs were incurred to assist with
the acceleration of the initial production. The water handling system was limited in its ability to process water from the production process. Disposal of this excess water required utilizing third
parties to transport water to approved disposal sites. This resulted in higher water disposal costs. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Depreciation, Depletion and Amortization  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation, depletion and amortization are comprised of depreciation on our Fort Union plant using the units-of-production method, based
on actual tons processed and depreciation on other fixed assets using the straight-line method, depletion, based on actual tons mined at our mine sites in Ohio and Wyoming, and
amortization related to our patents. Depreciation, depletion and amortization expenses were $5.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 compared to $773,000 during the same period
ended 2005. The increases are primarily attributable to the acquisition of Buckeye in the second quarter of 2006. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Research and Development  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Research and development costs were $1.4&nbsp;million and $1.6&nbsp;million for the years ended 2006 and 2005, respectively. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Cost of License and Consulting Revenue  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cost of licensing and consulting revenue was $134,000 and $401,000 for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively. The decreases in these
costs were in direct correlation to the revenue recognized in 2005 on the licensing agreement we entered into in 2004. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>42</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=42,EFW="2184008",CP="EVERGREEN ENERGY INC.",DN="1",CHK=494453,FOLIO='42',FILE='DISK127:[08ZAG1.08ZAG13301]DO13301A.;11',USER='CMATTI',CD='21-MAR-2008;15:25' -->
<A NAME="page_do13301_1_43"> </A>
<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Asset Impairment Charges and bad debt  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Asset impairment and bad debt charges were $335,000 and $1.3&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively. In 2006, we wrote
off $295,000 of certain site specific costs, which we were evaluating for a future K-Fuel facility. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Through
a series of transactions, Pegasus became indebted to us for $2.7&nbsp;million. We have rights to collect payments under this note from Pegasus and to demand payment upon
certain events of default. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, we determined that Pegasus might not have sufficient contracts to continue to meet this obligation. Therefore, we have
recorded an allowance for bad debt for the note receivable of $1.3&nbsp;million. Despite this allowance, we retain all of our rights to collect payments under this note from Pegasus and to demand
payment upon certain events of default. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Interest Income  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest income was $5.6&nbsp;million and $1.9&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, respectively. The increase is attributed to
interest earned on our cash balance, which was significantly higher compared to the same period in 2005, primarily as a result of our public stock offering in February of 2006. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Other income, net  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other income was $1.1&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
2003, we completed an equity exchange transaction pursuant to which we transferred our interest in Pegasus Technologies,&nbsp;Inc. for full ownership of
K-Fuel&nbsp;LLC, now part of a wholly owned subsidiary named KFx Technology,&nbsp;LLC. As a part of this exchange transaction, we exchanged an intercompany working capital loan with
Pegasus with an outstanding balance of $9.4&nbsp;million for a contingent earn-out agreement of up to $9.4&nbsp;million in the aggregate, plus accrued interest (prime rate plus 500
basis points), payable out of a portion of future cash flows generated by Pegasus. Due to the contingent nature of this potential stream of future cash flows, we did not recognize an asset or any
associated income at the time of the exchange transaction. As a result of a
transfer of ownership interests, the earn-out provisions were triggered and we received a payment of $1.1&nbsp;million from Pegasus as a payment in full satisfaction of the
$9.4&nbsp;million obligation. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>2008 Liquidity and Capital Resources Discussion  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our cash will primarily be used to fund corporate operations and for capital expenditures for future K-Fuel and/or K-Direct facilities and
corporate purposes. Our capital expenditures for 2008 are expected to be less than $10&nbsp;million which includes Buckeye mining and development costs, and costs associated with K-Fuel
and K-Direct facilities. We expect that our capital expenditures budget for 2008 may increase as we proceed with the potential construction of future K-Fuel plants and obtain
additional funding for these projects. In July 2007, the fabricator of the boiler island completed certain fabrication and engineering work which provided an appropriate point to temporarily suspend
construction. We have classified this boiler as held for sale in the amount of $18.6&nbsp;million. We agreed with the fabricator to suspend further construction on the boiler. Effective
January&nbsp;31, 2008, we and the fabricator of the boiler island agreed to terminate the contract and as a result, all future financial obligations were also terminated. We have been in discussions
with several potential buyers for the sale of this boiler and anticipate the consummation of this sale in the future. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
believe because of the decision to suspend operations and construction at our Fort Union plant and mine sites, along with the anticipated cash flows from our Buckeye operations, that
our current cash level is sufficient to support our corporate operations, including starting preliminary site investigation, design, permitting and similar long-lead-time
activities related to K-Fuel plants and/or </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>43</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=43,EFW="2184008",CP="EVERGREEN ENERGY INC.",DN="1",CHK=679826,FOLIO='43',FILE='DISK127:[08ZAG1.08ZAG13301]DO13301A.;11',USER='CMATTI',CD='21-MAR-2008;15:25' -->
<A NAME="page_do13301_1_44"> </A>
<BR>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>K-Direct
plants located at coal-fired power generating and industrial facilities for at least the next twelve months. However, as we identify strategic opportunities to
accelerate projects of large-scale commercial K-Fuel facilities and/or K-Direct facilities, or other agreements such as joint ventures, we will need to obtain additional
funding. We plan to seek additional capital from time to time as needed principally through: (1)&nbsp;equity offerings or the exercise of outstanding options and warrants; (2)&nbsp;debt offerings;
and (3)&nbsp;partnering with third parties in the construction and operation for some of our large-scale commercial plants through the formation of joint ventures. While we believe we will obtain
additional capital through one or more of the alternatives described, we can provide no assurance that any of the alternatives will be available to us or be on terms acceptable to us. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
July&nbsp;30, 2007, we completed the sale of $95.0&nbsp;million of long-term debt due 2012 that was resold in a private offering to qualified institutional buyers
pursuant to Rule&nbsp;144A under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended. The notes are senior, secured obligations guaranteed by our wholly owned subsidiary, Evergreen Operations,&nbsp;LLC, and
its subsidiaries, and secured by a first-priority security interest in (1)&nbsp;all of our equity interests in Evergreen Operations,&nbsp;LLC, (2)&nbsp;an escrow account established in
connection with the offering, and (3)&nbsp;our and each of our subsidiaries' bank, investment,
brokerage or similar accounts holding cash and cash equivalents, subject to certain exceptions. We will pay interest semi-annually at a rate of 8.00% per annum, due on February&nbsp;1
and August&nbsp;1 of each year, beginning on February&nbsp;1, 2008. The notes mature on August&nbsp;1, 2012. We incurred costs of $6.0&nbsp;million in connection with the sale of the notes.
Pursuant to the offering, we deposited $18.0&nbsp;million of the net proceeds in the escrow account referred to above. We plan on using the remaining proceeds for Buckeye capital expenditures, for
general corporate purposes and future construction of K-Fuel or K-Direct facilities. </FONT></P>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If
(1)&nbsp;the closing price of our common stock for at least 20 trading days in any 30 consecutive trading day period is at least the conversion price, or the reduced interest rate
threshold, and (2)&nbsp;if the shelf registration statement covering resales of the notes and the common stock issuable upon conversion of the notes is effective and available for use for at least
30&nbsp;days following the reduced interest rate threshold, unless registration is no longer required, then the initial interest rate will be permanently decreased to 5.00%. In addition, if
(1)&nbsp;the closing price of our common stock for at least 20 trading days in any 30 consecutive trading day period is at least 130% of the then applicable conversion price, or the collateral
release threshold, and (2)&nbsp;if the shelf registration statement covering resales of the notes and the common stock issuable upon conversion of the notes is effective and available for use for at
least 30&nbsp;days following the collateral release threshold, unless registration is no longer required, then the security will be released, including the $18.0&nbsp;million held in escrow, and
the notes will become automatically subordinated. At such time as the security is released, we may redeem the notes at a redemption price payable in cash equal to 100% of the principal amount, plus
any accrued and unpaid interest and an additional "coupon make-whole payment." The "coupon make-whole" amount per $1,000 principal amount of notes will be equal to the present
value of all remaining scheduled payments of interest on each note to be redeemed through the maturity date. On October&nbsp;29, 2007, we and the subsidiary guarantors filed a
post-effective amendment and prospectus supplement to our shelf registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the resale of the notes, guarantees and the
shares of common stock issuable upon conversion of the notes. The registration statement, post-effective amendment and prospectus supplement were automatically effective upon filing with
the Securities and Exchange Commission. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
February 2006, we sold approximately 8.1&nbsp;million shares of common stock at a price to the public of $18.75 per share pursuant to a follow-on common stock offering,
resulting in net proceeds of approximately $144.6&nbsp;million after deducting the underwriting discounts and commissions and estimated offering expenses. We used part of the proceeds from this
offering to fund the acquisition of Buckeye and the construction of our Fort Union plant. We plan on using the remaining funds for new K-Fuel and K-Direct facility construction
costs and general corporate purposes. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>44</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_do13301_1_45"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Payment Obligations  </B></FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table summarizes our future commitments as of December&nbsp;31, 2007: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;This
table does not include accounts payable, accrued expenses, or asset retirement obligations, which are reported in our December&nbsp;31, 2007 Consolidated Balance Sheet. We
generally have not included any obligation in which either party has the right to terminate except as discussed below. Additionally, we have not included royalty payments, as we cannot presently
determine when such payments will be made as such payments are based upon our receipt of cash for licensing and royalties. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
are obligated under non-cancelable operating leases with initial terms exceeding one year relating to office space. Rent expense for the years ended December&nbsp;31,
2007, 2006 and 2005 was $784,000, $415,000 and $242,000, respectively. Additionally, included in operating leases is the rent obligation associated with our former headquarters totaling $942,000 a
portion of which we have sub-leased but are not released from the obligation. Furthermore, included in operating leases is a dock lease on the Ohio River, which we have the right to cancel
upon six months written notice. If this lease were cancelled as of December&nbsp;31, 2007, we would be obligated to pay $250,000 rather than the entire obligation of $24.5&nbsp;million reflected
in the above table. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Consulting
and service commitments include an exclusive patent sub-license agreement with the developer of a proprietary technology for the measurement of carbon emissions.
The agreement provides us with an exclusive worldwide sub-license to a technology to standardize the measurement of carbon emissions in energy and agricultural related activities. The
agreement was amended and restated to expand the energy and agricultural activities to all applications of the technology and to eliminate other operating requirements. In order to maintain this
licensing arrangement, we are required to make minimum annual royalty payments of $500,000 to the developer of the proprietary technology, with each payment extending the arrangement for one year if
the parties are in material compliance with the contract. Additionally, consulting and service commitments includes our amended and restated our umbrella agreement with Bechtel. Through this new
program management agreement, we committed to provide Bechtel with $1&nbsp;billion in construction contracts through 2013. Failure to meet this commitment by 2014 could cost us up to the
$10&nbsp;million in termination fees, which is included in the above table. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Long-term
debt includes our principal amount due 2012 and the 8% interest payments. </FONT></P>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B>Historical View  </B></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Cash Used in Operating Activities  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash used in operating activities was $51.6&nbsp;million, $30.4&nbsp;million and $12.1&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007, 2006 and
2005, respectively. The majority of the cash used in operating activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 relates to cash utilized in our on-going operations, as adjusted for
non-cash items and changes in operating assets and liabilities. The most significant adjustment for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 was a $122.7&nbsp;million impairment charges.
Other significant adjustments to net loss to arrive at cash used in operating activities for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006 were: non-cash compensation expense of
$19.6&nbsp;million and $11.5&nbsp;million </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>45</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>

<A NAME="page_do13301_1_46"> </A>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>in
2007 and 2006, respectively and depreciation, depletion and amortization of $8.4&nbsp;million and $5.5&nbsp;million, respectively, primarily from the acquisition of Buckeye. The most
significant adjustments to net loss for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 were non-cash expense related to the issuance of warrants and options to employees, directors and
consultants of $11.0&nbsp;million and a $1.3&nbsp;million non-cash charge to establish an allowance for a note receivable. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Cash Used in Investing Activities  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash used in investing activities was $50.2&nbsp;million and $110.9&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, respectively. The
majority of the uses of cash relate to the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
paid $36.9&nbsp;million to consummate the Buckeye acquisition in 2006.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
purchased $74.6&nbsp;million and $113.3&nbsp;million of marketable securities and received $101.7&nbsp;million and $85.6&nbsp;million in proceeds from the
maturity of marketable securities for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006, respectively.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
spent $49.4&nbsp;million and $41.5&nbsp;million primarily on our Fort Union plant and future plant sites for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and 2006,
respectively.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
had capital expenditures related to other purchases of property and equipment of $4.1&nbsp;million and $5.2&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007
and 2006, respectively, and $1.0&nbsp;million for purchases of mineral rights and mine development for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>In
2007, we were required to restrict cash and marketable securities to serve as collateral of $24.7&nbsp;million, related to our $95&nbsp;million long-term
debt due 2012 and to collateralize other contractual obligations and our asset retirement obligations. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
used in investing activities was $73.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005. The majority of the uses of cash related to the following; </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
spent $47.1&nbsp;million on our Fort Union plant.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
purchased $54.7&nbsp;million of marketable securities and received $30.8&nbsp;million in proceeds from the maturity of marketable securities.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
had capital expenditures related to other purchases of property and equipment of $851,000.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
were required to restrict $1.8&nbsp;million of cash and marketable securities to collateralize other contractual obligations and our asset retirement obligation. </FONT></DD></DL>


<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2><B><I> Cash Provided by Financing Activities  </I></B></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash provided by financing activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 was $96.1&nbsp;million compared to $169.1&nbsp;million for the same period
ended 2006. The majority of the cash provided and used by financing activities relate to the following: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
received $95.0&nbsp;million from the issuance of long-term debt and paid $5.8&nbsp;million in debt issuance costs during the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2007.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
received $144.6&nbsp;million of cash from our public offering in February 2006.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='font-family:times;margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>We
received $4.9&nbsp;million and $24.6&nbsp;million in proceeds from the exercises of stock options and warrants during the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2007 and
2006, respectively </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
provided by financing activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005 was $11.5&nbsp;million. We received cash related to the exercise of options and warrants of
$11.7&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER" style="font-family:times;"><FONT SIZE=2>46</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<P style='font-family:times;page-break-before:always'></p>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=46,EFW="2184008",CP="EVERGREEN ENERGY INC.",DN="1",CHK=628879,FOLIO='46',FILE='DISK127:[08ZAG1.08ZAG13301]DO13301A.;11',USER='CMATTI',CD='21-MAR-2008;15:25' -->
